However, the rate of deactivation is progressively reduced with an increase in temperature.\n          The relatively slow deactivation of FeZSM-5 at 773 K can be associated with the high N2O conversion measured after 400 min on stream (72%, see Figure 4).\n          Previous studies have concluded that the ODH of propane with O2 over FeZSM-5 leads to very low C3H6 yields (<5%) as compared to N2O.\n          The degree of C3H8 conversion (after 2 min on stream) was very similar in both cases (ca. 50%), but the C3H6 selectivity decreased from 46% to 22% upon O2 addition, leading to an increased amount of COx.\n          Such intermediates appear to be essential for propene production. Accordingly, the performance of FeZSM-5 in the N2O-mediated ODH of propane is severely deteriorated in the presence of small amounts of O2.\n          Because the initial ODHP performance was recovered upon air-regeneration of the spent catalyst, a process for continuous propylene production via alternation of reaction and regeneration cycles has been evaluated.\n          The participation of the oxidant in coke oxidation above a certain reaction temperature may also explain the similar final coke content obtained in FeZSM-5 at 723 and 773 K.\n          The results in Figure 7 differ from those reported by Bulnek et al.9 These authors concluded that although the propene selectivity over H-ZSM-5 (301200 ppm Fe) was decreased in N2O+O2 as compared to N2O, the propene yield was not significantly changed, due to the increased propene conversion in the presence of O2.\n          The efficient utilization of N2O in tail-gases should involve a previous purification step. As shown here, the presence of O2 (a typical component of tail-gases) has a negative impact on the N2O-mediated propane oxidative dehydrogenation to propylene over FeZSM-5.", "English": "N2O is a highly efficient oxidant for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) over steam-activated FeZSM-5, achieving propene yields up to 25% at 723 K. The remarkable performance of iron zeolites in ODHP is attributed to the specificity of N2O as a monooxygen donor and the capability of iron forms in the zeolite to coordinate reactive atomic oxygen species for efficient dehydrogenation of propane. However, a major drawback is the deactivation by coke formation, leading to a rapid decrease in propene yield. The rate of deactivation is reduced with an increase in temperature, and the relatively slow deactivation of FeZSM-5 at 773 K is associated with high N2O conversion. The use of O2 as an oxidant in ODHP over FeZSM-5 leads to very low C3H6 yields (<5%) compared to N2O. The addition of small amounts of O2 to the C3H8+N2O mixture results in a decrease in C3H6 selectivity and an increase in COx production. The intermediates essential for propene production are negatively impacted by the presence of O2, severely deteriorating the performance of FeZSM-5 in N2O-mediated ODHP of propane. Strategies to address the limitations of catalyst deactivation and stability in N2O-ODHP include optimizing the reaction temperature to reduce deactivation rates, developing catalysts with improved resistance to coke formation, and exploring methods to regenerate the catalysts more efficiently. Research directions could focus on understanding the mechanisms of coke formation and identifying catalysts with active sites that are less susceptible to deactivation. Additionally, the development of cheap and selective catalyst systems for the low-temperature NH3 oxidation to N2O could provide a low-cost and reasonably pure source of N2O, making the process more feasible for practical implementation.", "Chinese": "N2O是过蒸汽活化FeZSM-5在氧化脱氢丙烷(ODHP)中的一种高效氧化剂，在723K时可达到25%的丙烯产量。铁沸石在ODHP中的优异性能归因于N2O作为单氧供体的特异性以及沸石中铁形式协调反应性原子氧物种以有效脱氢丙烷的能力。然而，一个主要缺点是由于焦炭形成导致的催化剂失活，导致丙烯产量迅速下降。失活速率随温度升高而降低，FeZSM-5在773K时的相对缓慢失活与高N2O转化率有关。在FeZSM-5上使用O2作为ODHP的氧化剂导致与N2O相比非常低的C3H6产量(<5%)。在C3H8+N2O混合物中添加少量O2导致C3H6选择性降低，COx产量增加。对丙烯生产至关重要的中间体受O2存在负面影响，严重恶化FeZSM-5在N2O介导的丙烷ODHP中的性能。解决N2O-ODHP中催化剂失活和稳定性限制的策略包括优化反应温度以降低失活速率，开发具有改善抗焦炭形成能力的催化剂，以及探索更有效地再生催化剂的方法。研究方向可以集中在理解焦炭形成机制和识别对失活不那么敏感的活性位点的催化剂上。此外，开发廉价和选择性的催化剂系统用于低温NH3氧化为N2O，可以提供低成本和相当纯净的N2O来源，使该过程更适用于实际应用。", "Doi": "10.1021/ie0493863"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide a direct comparison of N2O as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) with other oxidants in terms of propylene selectivity. However, it does state that N2O is more selective than molecular oxygen in other oxidation reactions. The literature discusses the use of nickel molybdate catalysts in the ODHP process and the effects of adding N2O as a gas dope on the catalytic performance. The addition of N2O modifies the catalytic performances, with a decrease in propane conversion, an increase in propylene yield and selectivity, and a decrease in oxygen consumption and CO2 yield at low concentrations of N2O. At higher concentrations of N2O, the selectivity in propylene decreases, and carbonaceous products are formed. The literature does not address the critical challenges associated with catalyst deactivation and stability in the N2O-ODHP process. However, it does suggest that adjusting the concentration of promoters like N2O could be a useful tool to modulate the oxidation state of oxide catalysts and improve their catalytic performances.", "Chinese": "文献没有直接比较N2O作为氧化剂在丙烷氧化脱氢(ODHP)过程中的丙烯选择性与其他氧化剂。但是，它确实指出N2O在其他氧化反应中比分子氧更具选择性。文献讨论了镍钼催化剂在ODHP过程中的应用以及添加N2O作为气体助剂对催化性能的影响。添加N2O会改变催化性能，丙烷转化率降低，丙烯产率和选择性增加，氧气消耗和CO2产率降低，当N2O浓度较低时。当N2O浓度较高时，丙烯的选择性降低，形成碳质产物。文献没有讨论N2O-ODHP过程中与催化剂失活和稳定性相关的关键挑战。但是，它确实建议，调整N2O等促进剂的浓度可能是一种有用的工具，可以调节氧化物催化剂的氧化状态，从而改善其催化性能。", "Doi": "10.1016/S0926-860X(03)00103-0"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Recently, it has been pro- posed to use nitrous oxide instead of dioxygen as oxidant, and the oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes with N2O has attracted con- siderable attention [213].\"\n          [2] \"During the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes with dioxygen, carbon oxides (CO and CO2) are extensively formed by over-oxidation even at moderate alkane conversions, resulting in low olefin selectivity and olefin yield [1].\"\n          [3] \"Iron-zeolites have been developed as unique catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes with N2O, especially the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propylene (ODHP).\"\n          [4] \"In our previous work, Fe-ZSM-5 prepared via a solid-state exchange method using ferrocene as iron precursor has been found to exhibit superior performance for the ODHP with N2O after a severe calcination.\"\n          [5] \"Catalyst deactivation is a key issue in the reaction of oxidative dehydrogenation, no matter whether dioxygen or nitrous oxide is used as oxidant.\"\n          [6] \"In the case of the ODHP with N2O, the presence of the propane reductant in the reaction system makes the conversion of nitrous oxide on iron-zeolites much more complicated.\"\n          [7] \"Another essential problem is the deactivation mecha- nism of catalysts in the ODHP with N2O.\"\n          [8] \"Accordingly, there is no effective means to prevent the deposition of coke and to increase the catalyst lifetime in the ODHP with N2O.\"", "English": "The use of nitrous oxide (N2O) as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) has gained significant attention as an alternative to dioxygen. The primary advantage of N2O is its ability to produce propylene with higher selectivity compared to dioxygen, which tends to over-oxidize propane, leading to the formation of carbon oxides (CO and CO2) and lower olefin yields. Iron-zeolites, particularly Fe-ZSM-5, have been developed as unique catalysts for this process, with Fe-ZSM-5 exhibiting superior performance for ODHP with N2O after severe calcination. However, catalyst deactivation remains a critical challenge in the ODHP process, regardless of the oxidant used. The presence of propane as a reductant complicates the conversion of nitrous oxide on iron-zeolites, and the deactivation mechanism of catalysts in ODHP with N2O is not fully understood. Strategies to address these limitations could include further research into the deactivation mechanisms, development of more stable catalysts, and optimization of reaction conditions to minimize coke formation and maximize catalyst lifetime. These efforts could potentially make N2O-ODHP a more feasible option for practical implementation.", "Chinese": "使用一氧化二氮(N2O)作为氧化剂在丙烷氧化脱氢(ODHP)中的应用已引起广泛关注，作为氧气的替代品。N2O的主要优势在于其能够以更高的选择性生产丙烯，与氧气相比，氧气倾向于过度氧化丙烷，导致二氧化碳(CO和CO2)的形成和较低的烯烃产量。铁沸石，特别是Fe-ZSM-5，已被开发为这种过程的独特催化剂，Fe-ZSM-5在N2O的ODHP中表现出优越的性能，经过严重煅烧。然而，催化剂失活仍然是ODHP过程中的一个关键挑战，无论使用哪种氧化剂。丙烷作为还原剂的存在使一氧化二氮在铁沸石上的转化复杂化，而N2O-ODHP中催化剂的失活机制尚未完全理解。解决这些限制的策略可能包括进一步研究失活机制，开发更稳定的催化剂，以及优化反应条件以最小化焦炭的形成并最大化催化剂的寿命。这些努力可能使N2O-ODHP成为更可行的实践实施选择。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.micromeso.2014.07.032"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"By replacement of O2 with N2O, overall activity decreased, while the selectivity towards propene formation increased for the same degree of propane conversion.\"\n          [2] \"Since N2O decomposition, over the studied mate- rials, is less favourable than O2 activation, a decrease in the steady-state concentration of active sites and an increase of the propene selectivity is achieved.\"\n          [3] \"A high selectivity to propene can be achieved by covering the support fully by well-dispersed vanadia species.\"\n          [4] \"The steady-state concentration of active lattice oxygen, which takes part in propane and propene activation, should be optimised to control selective ox- idation and combustion reactions. This was achieved by using N2O instead of O2.\"", "English": "The use of nitrous oxide (N2O) as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) has the advantage of increasing propylene selectivity compared to other oxidants. This is because N2O decomposition is less favorable than O2 activation, leading to a decrease in the steady-state concentration of active sites and an increase in propene selectivity. The efficiency of isolated VOx species for selective ODHP is superimposed by non-selective oxidation over the naked surface of the acidic support, which is not covered by active vanadia. To achieve high performance in ODHP, it is desirable to design catalytic surfaces that are fully covered by well-dispersed vanadia species to avoid the strong adsorption of propene on the support surface. The steady-state concentration of active lattice oxygen, which takes part in propane and propene activation, should be optimized to control selective oxidation and combustion reactions. Using N2O instead of O2 can achieve this optimization.", "Chinese": "在丙烷氧化脱氢（ODHP）中使用一氧化二氮（N2O）作为氧化剂，与其它氧化剂相比，具有提高丙烯选择性的优势。这是因为N2O分解不如O2激活有利，导致活性位点的稳态浓度降低，丙烯选择性增加。孤立VOx物种在选择性ODHP中的效率被非选择性氧化所叠加，这种氧化发生在未被活性矾覆盖的酸性支撑表面。为了在ODHP中实现高性能，设计催化表面是可取的，这些表面完全被分散良好的矾物种覆盖，以避免丙烯在支撑表面上的强烈吸附。参与丙烷和丙烯活化的活性晶格氧的稳态浓度应进行优化，以控制选择性氧化和燃烧反应。使用N2O代替O2可以实现这种优化。", "Doi": "10.1016/S0926-860X(01)00836-5"},
{"Quotes": "For all V/MCM-41 catalysts used in this study, higher propene selectivity is achieved with N2O as compared with O2 at similar degrees of C3H8 conversion.\n          The catalytic activity is lower, however, in the presence of N2O as com- pared with O2 because of the weaker oxidizing potential of N2O relative to O2 for the re-oxidation of the reduced surface VOx sites during the ODP reaction.\n          There is no significant difference in propene selectivity between highly dispersed surface VOx species and crystalline V2O5 nanoparticles when N2O is used as an oxidant.\n          In contrast to highly dispersed VOx on the surface of MCM-41, the crystalline V2O5 nanoparticles are not selective for the ODP reaction in the presence of O2.\n          The positive effect of N2O is related to the inhibition of direct C3H8 oxidation and the consecutive oxidation of C3H6 to COx.\n          The inhibition is ascribed to reducing surface density (spatial separation) of active surface lattice oxygen in VOx species, since N2O is a weaker oxidant for re-oxidation of reduced VOx species as compared with O2.\n          From a stoichiometric point of view of the ODP reaction, selective propene formation is favored over combustion reactions at lower surface densities.", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been found to be advantageous as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) due to its ability to achieve higher propene selectivity compared to molecular oxygen (O2) at similar degrees of propane conversion. This is attributed to the weaker oxidizing potential of N2O, which inhibits the direct oxidation of propane and the consecutive oxidation of propene to carbon oxides (COx). The use of N2O as an oxidant results in a lower catalytic activity due to its weaker ability to re-oxidize the reduced surface vanadium oxide (VOx) species. However, there is no significant difference in propene selectivity between highly dispersed surface VOx species and crystalline V2O5 nanoparticles when N2O is used as an oxidant. In contrast, crystalline V2O5 nanoparticles are not selective for the ODHP reaction in the presence of O2. The positive effect of N2O on propene selectivity is related to the reduction in surface density (spatial separation) of active surface lattice oxygen in VOx species, as N2O is a weaker oxidant for re-oxidation of reduced VOx species compared to O2. From a stoichiometric point of view, selective propene formation is favored over combustion reactions at lower surface densities.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮(N2O)已被发现作为氧化脱氢丙烷(ODHP)的氧化剂具有优势,因为它在与氧气(O2)相似的丙烷转化程度下,能够实现更高的丙烯选择性。这归因于N2O较弱的氧化电位,它抑制了丙烷的直接氧化和丙烯连续氧化为一氧化碳和二氧化碳(COx)。使用N2O作为氧化剂导致较低的催化活性,因为N2O较弱的能力重新氧化表面钒氧化物(VOx)的还原形式。然而,当N2O用作氧化剂时,高度分散的表面VOx物种和结晶V2O5纳米粒子之间在丙烯选择性上没有显著差异。相比之下,在O2存在下,结晶V2O5纳米粒子对ODHP反应没有选择性。N2O对丙烯选择性的正面影响与表面VOx物种中活性表面晶格氧的表面密度(空间分离)降低有关,因为N2O与O2相比,是一种较弱的氧化剂,用于还原VOx物种的重新氧化。从ODHP反应的化学计量观点来看,在较低的表面密度下,选择性丙烯形成比燃烧反应更受青睐。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2005.05.025"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"In our recent studies of the ODP reaction over VOx/ g-Al2O3 [5] and VOx/MCM-41 [6] catalytic materials it was demonstrated that propene selectivity could be increased when O2 was replaced by N2O. The most significant improvements in propene selectivity (up to three times) were achieved for the sample possessing bulk like V2O5 species. It was suggested that the improved ODP performance with N2O was due to the lower ability of N2O for re-oxidation of reduced VOx species, i.e. the degree of catalyst reduction in the presence of N2O is higher than in the presence of O2.\"\n          [2] \"The results of steady-state ODP studies in Fig. 2 suggest a complex reaction scheme of parallel and consecutive steps for the ODP reaction using either O2 or N2O. The scheme is presented in Fig. 8. According to this scheme, the importance of direct (not via consecutive propene oxidation) propane oxidation to COx (mainly to CO2) is significantly higher in the presence of O2 than in N2O.\"\n          [3] \"The results in Table 4 indicate that a higher initial propene selectivity is achieved with N2O than with O2 for all the studied vanadium oxides using C3H8/N2O/Ne = 40/40/20 and C3H8/ O2/Ne = 40/20/40 reaction feeds.\"\n          [4] \"The difference between O2- and N2O-containing ODP feeds in the catalytic performance of vanadium oxides (Fig. 2, Table 4) may be partially related to the nature of active oxygen species originating from O2.\"\n          [5] \"The oxidizing agent tunes the catalytic performance of the studied vanadium oxides. As compared to O2-containing feeds, direct C3H8 oxidation to CO and CO2 (mainly) as well as consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx are drastically reduced in the presence of N2O. The corresponding improved initial C3H6 selectivity can be related to the degree of reduction of vanadium sites; the higher the degree, the higher the selectivity. It is assumed that also the nature of oxygen species originated from O2 and N2O differs and plays a role in consecutive C3H6 and direct C3H8 oxidation.\"\n          [6] \"In our recent studies of the ODP reaction over VOx/ g-Al2O3 [5] and VOx/MCM-41 [6] catalytic materials it was demonstrated that propene selectivity could be increased when O2 was replaced by N2O. The most significant improvements in propene selectivity (up to three times) were achieved for the sample possessing bulk like V2O5 species. It was suggested that the improved ODP performance with N2O was due to the lower ability of N2O for re-oxidation of reduced VOx species, i.e. the degree of catalyst reduction in the presence of N2O is higher than in the presence of O2.\"\n          [7] \"For both oxidizing agents, propene selectivity decreases with an increase in propane conversion. This is due to a consecutive C3H6 oxidation to CO and CO2. However, these non-selective reaction pathways are influenced by the nature of oxidizing agent. From the results in Fig. 2(a) it is clear that propene selectivity decreases with an increase in the degree of propane conversion stronger with O2 than with N2O. For an O2- containing reaction feed, C3H6 selectivity decreases from 77 to 15% upon increasing C3H8 conversion from 0.6 to 9%. For similar changes in the degree of C3H8 conversion in the presence of N2O, C3H6 selectivity drops only from 86 to 60%.\"\n          [8] \"The reaction pathways of CO and CO2 formation are also influenced by the nature of oxidizing agent. It is clearly seen from the selectivityconversion plot in Fig. 2(b) that CO2 selectivity only slightly changes with varying degree of C3H8 conversion when O2 is used as oxidizing agent. It increases from 15 to 20% upon increasing C3H8 conversion from 0.6 to 9%. About 13% CO2 selectivity is expected upon extrapolation to a zero degree of propane conversion. Based on this observation and taking into account the small change of CO2 selectivity with varying degree of propane conversion in Fig. 2(b), it is concluded that carbon dioxide is mainly formed via direct propane combustion but not via consecutive propene oxidation. The latter reaction contributes to the total CO2 production only at high degrees of propane conversion. When O2 is replaced by N2O, CO2 selectivity decreases in the studied range of propane conversions (Fig. 2(b)). The decrease in CO2 selectivity is explained by a reduced tendency towards direct propane combustion. This conclusion is based on the fact, that a near-to-zero CO2 selectivity is expected for a zero degree of propane conversion in the presence of N2O (Fig. 2(b)). Upon increasing C3H8 conversion, CO2 selectivity increases, hence, CO2 is mainly formed via consecutive C3H6 oxidation when N2O is used as oxidizing agent.\"\n          [9] \"The selectivityconversion plot in Fig. 2(c) evidences that CO formation is stronger influenced by the degree of C3H8 conversion than CO2 formation. CO selectivity is very low (<5%) at zero C3H8 conversion but strongly increases with C3H8 conversion for both oxidants (N2O and O2). The obtained relationship indicates the secondary nature of CO formation,i.e. CO is formed via consecutive C3H6 oxidation. From Fig. 2(c) it is concluded that CO formation with O2 is stronger influenced by the degree of C3H8 conversion as compared to the tests with N2O. For an O2-containing feed, a relative difference in CO selectivity is 60% upon increasing C3H8 conversion from 0.6 to 9%, while the respective differencewith N2O is 20%.\"\n          [10] \"Summarizing the above discussion, it is concluded that catalytic performance and general scheme of the ODP reaction are determined by the applied oxidizing agent (O2 and N2O),but not by the initial composition of individual vanadium oxides.\"\n          [11] \"The results of steady-state ODP studies in Fig. 2 suggest a complex reaction scheme of parallel and consecutive steps for the ODP reaction using either O2 or N2O. The scheme is presented in Fig. 8. According to this scheme, the importance of direct (not via consecutive propene oxidation) propane oxidation to COx (mainly to CO2) is significantly higher in the presence of O2 than in N2O. Hence, the catalytic performance is determined by the oxidant activation, since this is a necessary stage for the heterogeneous reactions of partial oxidation [8,26].\"\n          [12] \"Based on the above discussion, the degree of reduction of vanadium species (bulk and surface) is suggested to be a key factor influencing initial propene selectivity. However, the reduction degree is not the only catalyst property, which determines the catalyst ability for consecutive propene oxidation to COx. This conclusion is based on the fact that the reduction degree of vanadium species in V2O5 after the ODP reaction using C3H8/N2O/Ne = 40/40/20 and C3H8/O2/ Ne = 40/10/50 feeds is similar (Table 3) but the catalytic performance is different (Fig. 9, Table 4). The difference between O2- and N2O-containing ODP feeds in the catalytic performance of vanadium oxides (Fig. 2, Table 4) may be partially related to the nature of active oxygen species originating from O2. To support this assumption, we performed transient experiments with isotopically labeled 18O2 using a SSITKA (steady-state isotopic transient kinetic analysis) technique. The idea is to follow distribution of non-labeled (16O) oxygen (lattice oxygen of vanadium oxides) and labeled (18O) oxygen (adsorbed oxygen) in carbon dioxide. The results are presented and discussed below.\"\n          [13] \"The oxidizing agent tunes the catalytic performance of the studied vanadium oxides. As compared to O2-containing feeds, direct C3H8 oxidation to CO and CO2 (mainly) as well as consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx are drastically reduced in the presence of N2O. The corresponding improved initial C3H6 selectivity can be related to the degree of reduction of vanadium sites; the higher the degree, the higher the selectivity. It is assumed that also the nature of oxygen species originated from O2 and N2O differs and plays a role in consecutive C3H6 and direct C3H8 oxidation.\"", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been shown to increase propylene selectivity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) compared to other oxidants like oxygen (O2). This improvement is attributed to the lower ability of N2O to re-oxidize reduced vanadium oxide (VOx) species, leading to a higher degree of catalyst reduction. The use of N2O can result in up to three times higher propylene selectivity compared to O2, especially when the catalyst contains bulk-like V2O5 species. N2O reduces the tendency for direct propane combustion and consecutive propene oxidation to COx, leading to improved initial propene selectivity. The nature of oxygen species originating from O2 and N2O also plays a role in the selectivity and activity of the catalyst.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮(N2O)已被证明在丙烷氧化脱氢(ODHP)中提高丙烯选择性,与氧气(O2)等其他氧化剂相比。这种改进归因于N2O降低还原钒氧化物(VOx)物种的能力,导致催化剂还原度更高。使用N2O可以产生高达三倍的丙烯选择性,特别是当催化剂含有类似块状的V2O5物种时。N2O减少了直接丙烷燃烧和连续丙烯氧化为COx的倾向,从而提高了初始丙烯选择性。源自O2和N2O的氧物种的性质也在选择性和催化剂活性中发挥作用。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.apcata.2006.11.021"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"In our recent studies of the ODP reaction over alumina- and silica-supported vanadia catalysts, 20,36 it was demonstrated that propene selectivity increases upon replacing O2 with N2O. Since the ODP activity with N2O was lower than with O2,20 we suggested that the degree of reduction of VOx species might be important for achieving high propene selectivity.\"\n          [2] \"The results of physicochemical characterization of VOx/SiO2, VOx/MCM-41, and VOx/MCM-48 materials; their catalytic performance in the ODP reaction; and redox dynamics of VOx species from in-situ UV/vis analysis are presented in sections 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3, respectively.\"\n          [3] \"The lower ability of N2O for reoxidation of reduced VOx species is also responsible for the lower ODP activity with N2O than with O2 as was previously suggested for VOx/MCM-4120 and VOx/γ-Al2O336 catalytic materials.\"\n          [4] \"The results of steady-state ODP studies suggest a complex reaction scheme of parallel and consecutive steps for the ODP reaction using either O2 or N2O. According to this scheme, C3H8 is directly converted to C3H6 and COx, with the latter reaction path playing a significant role for VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample possessing microcrystalline V2O5. The formed propene is further converted to CO and CO2. The importance of direct (not via consecutive propene oxidation) propane and consecutive propene oxidation to COx is significantly higher in the presence of O2 than in N2O. Hence, the catalytic performance is determined by the oxidant activation.\"\n          [5] \"Besides influencing the reduction degree of VOx species, N2O does not produce nonselective adsorbed oxygen species (possibly of biatomic nature), which are formed from O2 and catalyze nonselective consecutive propene oxidation to COx.\"\n          [6] \"The results of our detailed physicochemical characterization (transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), UV/vis, Raman, and X-ray diffraction (XRD)) analysis of VOx/MCM-41 materials have been previously published,20 the most relevant results are briefly reported together with those for VOx/SiO2 and VOx/MCM-48.\"\n          [7] \"The XRD patterns of VOx/MCM-48 and VOx/SiO2 with vanadium loading up to ca. 5 wt % do not show any signs of crystalline V2O5 phase.\"\n          [8] \"The lowest TOF value was obtained over the VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample, where microcrystalline V2O5 phase was detected.\"\n          [9] \"The primary C3H6 selectivity is obtained from the intersect of the fitted line with the S(C3H6) axis, while the slope of the line represents the catalyst ability for consecutive propene oxidation to COx.\"\n          [10] \"This means that consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx (mainly to CO) is reduced in the presence of N2O.\"\n          [11] \"The higher polymerized VOx species, the higher their activity for consecutive propene oxidation.\"\n          [12] \"The lower ability of N2O for reoxidation of reduced VOx species is also responsible for the lower ODP activity with N2O than with O2 as was previously suggested for VOx/MCM-4120 and VOx/γ-Al2O336 catalytic materials.\"\n          [13] \"The results of our detailed physicochemical characterization (transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), UV/vis, Raman, and X-ray diffraction (XRD)) analysis of VOx/MCM-41 materials have been previously published,20 the most relevant results are briefly reported together with those for VOx/SiO2 and VOx/MCM-48.\"\n          [14] \"The BET values of unloaded MCM-41, MCM-48, and SiO2 support materials amounted to 1040, 1049, and 300 m2/g, respectively.\"\n          [15] \"Vanadium-loaded MCM-41 and SiO2 materials showed a decrease in the specific surface area by a factor of ca. 20% for vanadium loadings up to 5.3 wt %.\"\n          [16] \"The VOx(3.4)/MCM-48 catalyst lost ca. 50% of the original surface area of MCM-48.\"\n          [17] \"The SBET value (52 m2/g) of VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 is significantly lower than those of the other catalysts.\"\n          [18] \"As reported in ref 20, the pore structure of MCM-41 is completely destroyed in this sample.\"\n          [19] \"Small V2O5 crystallites were observed in this sample by means of ex-situ XRD analysis.\"\n          [20] \"The XRD patterns of VOx/MCM-48 and VOx/SiO2 with vanadium loading up to ca. 5 wt % do not show any signs of crystalline V2O5 phase.\"\n          [21] \"Additional UV/vis and Raman spectroscopic characterization studies (the data are not shown for brevity) did not indicate a possible presence of XRD-amorphous crystalline V2O5 nanoparticles for samples possessing up to 5.3 wt % vanadium.\"\n          [22] \"The calculated vanadium surface densities are 0.37, 0.6, 1.38, and 25.4 for VOx(2.7)/MCM-41, VOx(3.4)/MCM-48, VOx(2.9)/SiO2, and VOx(11.2)/MCM-41, respectively.\"\n          [23] \"On the basis of the obtained densities and the literature9 values for a vanadium monolayer (57 V/nm2), it can be safely concluded that all catalytic materials, except for VOx(11.2)/MCM-41, possess VOx species below one vanadium monolayer.\"\n          [24] \"A single maximum of H2 consumption at ca. 801 and 806 K was observed upon reduction of VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 and VOx (2.8)/SiO2, respectively.\"\n          [25] \"Additionally to the maximal H2 consumption at 810 K, a small shoulder at ca. 860 K was identified in the TPR profile of the VOx(3.4)/MCM-48 sample.\"\n          [26] \"This shoulder becomes more pronounced for the VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample, where crystalline V2O5 phase was identified by XRD analysis.\"\n          [27] \"According to the literature data,37,42,43 the peak at 864 K could be due to the presence of highly polymerized VOx species or crystalline V2O5.\"\n          [28] \"Summarizing the above discussion, it is concluded that the degree of polymerization of VOx species is influenced by the support material at apparent surface vanadium densities below one monolayer.\"\n          [29] \"The relative degree of polymerization of VOx species follows the order\"\n          [30] \"The VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample possesses microcrystalline V2O5 phase.\"\n          [31] \"The next section establishes correlations between the nature of VOx species and their performance in the ODP reaction with O2 and N2O.\"\n          [32] \"Catalytic performance of differently structured VOx species supported over MCM-41, SiO2, and MCM-48 was determined using C3H8/O2/Ne = 40/20/40 and C3H8/N2O/Ne = 40/40/20 reaction mixtures.\"\n          [33] \"Since the amount of N2O was double that of O2, both of the above reaction feeds contained the same amount of oxygen atoms.\"\n          [34] \"This allows the comparison of the influence of oxidizing agents on the ODP reaction.\"\n          [35] \"The TOF (turnover frequency) values of propane conversion in the presence of O2 and N2O over VOx species below (VOx(2.7)/MCM-41, VOx(2.8)/SiO2, and VOx(3.4)/MCM-48) and above (VOx(11.2)/MCM-41) one monolayer are compared in Table 1.\"\n          [36] \"The TOF values were calculated taking the total amount of vanadium atoms into account.\"\n          [37] \"This table illustrates that the catalytic activity of the VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 catalyst is slightly higher than that of the VOx(2.8)/SiO2 and VOx(3.4)/MCM-48 samples.\"\n          [38] \"This may be due to a lower degree of polymerization of VOx species over the VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 catalyst as shown in section 3.1.\"\n          [39] \"The lowest TOF value was obtained over the VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample, where microcrystalline V2O5 phase was detected.\"\n          [40] \"Irrespective of the structural difference of VOx species, the catalytic activity decreases when O2 is replaced by N2O.\"\n          [41] \"For establishing overall mechanistic scheme of the ODP reaction with O2 and N2O over VOx species of different degrees of polymerization, catalytic performance (product selectivity) was determined at different contact times, that is, different degrees of propane conversion.\"\n          [42] \"This knowledge is of high importance for catalyst designing, because it provides essential information on the sequence of product formation, that is, the catalyst ability for C3H8 conversion to C3H6 and COx as well as for consecutive C3H6 combustion.\"\n          [43] \"The obtained selectivityconversion relationships with O2 are summarized in Figure 1.\"\n          [44] \"Propene selectivity decreases, while CO and CO2 selectivities (the data are not shown) increase with an increase in the degree of propane conversion.\"\n          [45] \"Such behavior is explained by consecutive oxidation of the primarily formed propene to carbon oxides.\"\n          [46] \"For the VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample, the low propene selectivity at near-to-zero degree of propane conversion is an indication for catalytic activity toward direct (not via consecutive propene oxidation) propane oxidation to carbon oxides.\"\n          [47] \"This reaction pathway does not play any significant role over other catalytic materials with vanadium loading below one monolayer.\"\n          [48] \"Over the latter catalysts, CO and CO2 originate mainly via consecutive C3H6 oxidation.\"\n          [49] \"Figure 1b illustrates selectivityconversion relationships in the ODP reaction over differently structured VOx species using N2O.\"\n          [50] \"As in the presence of O2 (Figure 1a), propene selectivity decreases with an increase in propane conversion with N2O, too.\"\n          [51] \"However, from the comparison of the results in Figure 1a and b, it is obvious that propene selectivity is higher with N2O than with O2 over a broad range of degrees of propane conversion.\"\n          [52] \"This effect is more pronounced for the sample possessing microcrystalline V2O5.\"\n          [53] \"From a more detailed analysis of the data in Figure 1, the primary C3H6 selectivity (at near-to-zero degree of propane conversion) and the catalyst ability for consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx can be derived.\"\n          [54] \"These two parameters represent the catalyst activity for direct propane conversion to COx and for consecutive combustion of primarily formed propene, respectively.\"\n          [55] \"In the present paper, the dependence of S(C3H6) on X(C3H8) at low propane conversion (<10%) is described by a linear function in eq 1.\"\n          [56] \"where S(C3H6)initial and A are the primary propene selectivity and the catalyst ability for consecutive propene oxidation to COx, respectively.\"\n          [57] \"According to this function, the primary C3H6 selectivity is obtained from the intersect of the fitted line with the S(C3H6) axis, while the slope of the line represents the catalyst ability for consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx.\"\n          [58] \"This parameter is related to the catalyst activity for propene conversion to carbon oxides.\"\n          [59] \"The higher the slope of the function in eq 1, the faster the COx production from C3H6.\"\n          [60] \"Establishing the relationships between the catalyst ability for consecutive propene oxidation and the structure of VOx species or the applied oxidizing agent is highly relevant for designing selective catalysts, since propene selectivity in the ODP reaction suffers mainly from the higher reactivity of propene as compared to propane.\"\n          [61] \"Figure 2 compares the primary S(C3H6) and the catalyst ability (A) for consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx over differently structured VOx species in the presence of O2 and N2O.\"\n          [62] \"For an O2-containing reaction feed (C3H8/O2/Ne = 40/20/40), it is clear that the primary propene selectivity is close for VOx(2.7)/MCM-41, VOx(3.4)/MCM-48, and VOx(2.8)/SiO2 materials but is significantly low over VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 (Figure 2 a).\"\n          [63] \"From the characterization results in section 3.1, the latter material possesses microcrystalline V2O5 while other materials are free of microcrystalline V2O5 and possess highly dispersed two-dimensional VOx species.\"\n          [64] \"Figure 2b clearly demonstrates that consecutive propene oxidation is strongly influenced by the nature of VOx species, too.\"\n          [65] \"The following order of catalyst ability for propene oxidation was found:\"\n          [66] \"The degree of polymerization of VOx species follows the same order (section 3.1).\"\n          [67] \"Thus, the higher polymerized VOx species, the higher their activity for consecutive propene oxidation.\"\n          [68] \"This conclusion is in agreement with literature data9 and with our recent results of the ODP reaction on VOx/γ-Al2O3.36\"\n          [69] \"Further insights into the influence of oxidizing agent on product selectivity in the ODP reaction are derived from the analysis of CO/C3H6 and CO2/C3H6 ratios at different degrees of propane conversion.\"\n          [70] \"Table 1 represents these ratios at propane conversions of ca. 2 and 10%.\"\n          [71] \"For samples possessing highly dispersed VOx species, both of these ratios at a degree of propane conversion of ca. 2% decrease from ca. 0.1 to ca. 0.05 upon replacing O2 with N2O.\"\n          [72] \"However, the ratio of CO2/C3H6 over polymerized VOx species increases from 0.04 to 0.13, while the ratio of CO/C3H6 decreases from 1.7 to 0.27, when N2O is used instead of O2.\"\n          [73] \"For both oxidizing agents, the ratios of CO/C3H6 and CO2/C3H6 increase with propane conversion, with the former increasing stronger.\"\n          [74] \"This increase is less pronounced for a feed with N2O.\"\n          [75] \"This means that consecutive C3H6 oxidation to COx (mainly to CO) is reduced in the presence of N2O.\"\n          [76] \"This effect is more pronounced for polymerized VOx species.\"\n          [77] \"Summarizing, two important improving effects of N2O on the ODP reaction should be especially emphasized: (1) a higher primary C3H6 selectivity (at near-to-zero degree of C3H8 conversion) is achieved and (2) lower activity for consecutive propene oxidation.\"\n          [78] \"To elucidate possible reasons of the influence of oxidizing agent on the ODP performance of highly dispersed VOx species and microcrystalline V2O5, in-situ UV/vis measurements were performed at 773 K.\"\n          [79] \"The degrees of propane and oxidant (O2 and N2O) conversion were controlled by online mass spectrometry (MS).\"\n          [80] \"To ensure a near-to-uniform composition of the studied catalysts along the catalyst bed, propane and oxidant (O2 or N2O) conversions were kept below 5 and 10%, respectively.\"\n          [81] \"Figure 3 exemplifies in-situ UV/vis spectra of VOx(2.7)/MCM-41, VOx(2.8)/SiO2, and VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 in oxidizing (O2/Ne = 20/80) and reducing (H2/N2 = 5/95 or C3H8/Ne = 40/60) atmospheres as well as in ODP feeds (C3H8/O2/Ne = 40/20/40 or C3H8/N2O/Ne = 40/40/20).\"\n          [82] \"The UV/vis spectrum in a flow of O2 with the absorption at 295 nm is characteristic for tetrahedrally coordinated V5+Ox species.\"\n          [83] \"The adsorption in the 400700 nm region (dd transitions of reduced vanadium species) increases upon switching from an O2 flow to a H2 flow (Figure 3a); the UV/vis bands of V4+ and V3+ species appear as broad features in the 400800 nm region (note the nonzero value of the absorption for the reduced samples in this region).\"\n          [84] \"46,47 Similar changes were also observed when the oxidized catalyst was admitted to a C3H8 flow.\"\n          [85] \"Since no significant differences in the UV/vis spectra in H2 and C3H8 flows were observed (Figure 3a), the effect of possible carbon-containing deposits in the case of C3H8 flow on the interpretation of UV/vis data can therefore be neglected.\"\n          [86] \"Thus, the observed changes in the UV/vis spectra of VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 upon switching from oxidizing to reducing flows reflect the changes in reduction degree of VOx species under different reaction conditions.\"\n          [87] \"Taking the above discussion into account, the UV/vis spectra in O2 (20% O2 in Ne) and C3H8 (40% C3H8 in Ne) flows represent oxidized and reduced states of VOx species, respectively.\"\n          [88] \"In the following, we compare UV/vis spectra under different ODP conditions (C3H8/O2/Ne = 40/20/40 and C3H8/N2O/Ne = 40/40/20) with the spectra of oxidized and reduced VOx species to derive insights into the reduction degree of VOx species under reaction conditions.\"\n          [89] \"One can see from Figure 3 that the UV/vis spectra during the ODP reaction with O2 (C3H8/O2/Ne = 40/20/40) and in an O2 (O2/Ne = 20/80) flow are very similar.\"\n          [90] \"This means that the oxidation state of VOx species in both cases is close to 5+.\"\n          [91] \"However, there is a strong difference between the UV/vis spectra in O2 (O2/Ne = 20/80) and N2OC3H8 (N2O/C3H8/Ne = 40/40/20) flows, while the UV/vis spectra in H2 (H2/N2 = 5/95) and N2OC3H8 (N2O/C3H8/Ne = 40/40/20) flows are very similar.\"\n          [92] \"This evidence that the oxidation state of VOx species under conditions of the ODP reaction with N2O (X(C3H8) < 5%, X(N2O) < 10%) is similar to the reduced one.\"\n          [93] \"This means that the oxidation state of vanadium in VOx species decreases from 5+ to 3+ and/or 4+ when the ODP reaction is performed with N2O instead of O2.\"\n          [94] \"Another interesting observation from Figure 3 is the appearance of a new band at 400450 nm in the UV/vis spectrum of VOx(2.8)/SiO2 in a C3H8 (C3H8/Ne = 40/60) flow.\"\n          [95] \"A similar band was also identified over VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 after 1030 min on stream in C3H8.\"\n          [96] \"To prove whether this band may belong to carbon deposits, we performed time-on-stream in-situ UV/vis tests over VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 in a H2 flow (H2/N2 = 5/95).\"\n          [97] \"The results are shown in Figure 4.\"\n          [98] \"One can see that the band at 400450 nm starts to appear after 10 min and becomes apparent after 30 min on stream in a H2 flow.\"\n          [99] \"Since this band appears in the absence of carbon-containing species, its appearance due to coke deposition can be safely excluded.\"\n          [100] \"Possible origins of this band are discussed as follows.\"\n          [101] \"It is well-known that nondehydrated VOx/silica materials possess octahedral coordinated VOx species, in which adsorbed water is a ligand.\"\n          [102] \"On the basis of this experimental fact, it can be suggested that water is formed upon reaction of VOx species over SiO2 and MCM-41 with H2 and adsorbs over reduced VOx species increasing their coordination from tetrahedral to octahedral.\"\n          [103] \"However, to draw a more definitive conclusion about the origins of the band at 400450 nm in H2 at 773 K, new additional experiments are required.\"\n          [104] \"It is also important to stress that there is no difference in the UV/vis spectra of VOx species under oxidizing conditions before and after treatments in H2 (Figure 4).\"\n          [105] \"Similar results were obtained for all the oxidizing/reduction/reaction cycles described in Figure 3.\"\n          [106] \"This means that VOx species remain highly dispersed during the applied treatments and time-on-stream operation.\"\n          [107] \"To check if O2 and N2O show different ability (activity) for the reoxidation of reduced VOx species, in-situ UV/vis tests were performed in a transient mode.\"\n          [108] \"In these experiments, the oxidized sample was reduced in a flow of C3H8 (C3H8/Ne = 40/60) at 773 K for 10 min followed by flushing in a Ne flow for 1 min and feeding an O2 flow (O2/Ne = 20/80) over the reduced catalyst.\"\n          [109] \"The sample was kept in this flow for 30 min to reoxidate reduced VOx species.\"\n          [110] \"Hereafter, the reoxidized catalyst was again reduced in C3H8 followed by its reoxidation in a N2O (N2O/Ne = 40/60) flow.\"\n          [111] \"In all the above experiments, UV/vis spectra from 200 to 800 nm and KubelkaMunk at 700 nm were recorded every 20 and 5 s, respectively.\"\n          [112] \"The respective results are summarized in Figure 5 and Figure 6.\"\n          [113] \"It is clear from Figure 5 that there is no significant difference in the spectra of fully oxidized VOx species and VOx species having been reoxidized for 5 s in an O2 flow after C3H8 pretreatment.\"\n          [114] \"As compared to O2, reoxidation of reduced VOx species with N2O is slower, since these species are fully oxidized after ca. 30 s on steam in N2O.\"\n          [115] \"More detailed insights into the kinetics of reduction of oxidized VOx species by C3H8 and reoxidation of reduced ones by O2 and N2O were derived from the analysis of temporal changes in the KubelkaMunk function in Figure 6.\"\n          [116] \"At time zero, we switched from an O2 flow (O2/Ne = 20/80) to a C3H8 flow (C3H8/Ne = 40/60).\"\n          [117] \"As result, the KubelkaMunk function at 700 nm increases from 0 (fully oxidized VOx species) and reaches a constant value of ca. 0.2 after 5 min on C3H8 stream.\"\n          [118] \"Similar changes were observed when H2 was used as a reducing agent instead of C3H8.\"\n          [119] \"Therefore, we can safely conclude that the observed changes are due to the reduction of oxidized VOx species by propane and are not due to deposition of carbon-containing species in the case of C3H8.\"\n          [120] \"To prove whether the reduction/reoxidation of VOx species is a reversible process, an O2 flow (O2/Ne = 20/80) was fed over the reduced sample (at ca. 10 min in Figure 6) followed by C3H8 feeding (at ca. 22 min in Figure 6).\"\n          [121] \"As shown in Figure 6, the KubelkaMunk function at 700 nm falls from ca. 0.2 to 0 after a few seconds in the O2 flow and reversibly increases to 0.2 in the C3H8 flow.\"\n          [122] \"Two important conclusions were derived: (1) reduction/oxidation of VOx species is a reversible process and (2) reduction of oxidized VOx species by C3H8 is slower than reoxidation of reduced VOx species by O2.\"\n          [123] \"When N2O was used for the reoxidation of reduced VOx species (ca. 3240 min in Figure 6), these species were also reoxidized.\"\n          [124] \"However, the temporal changes in the KubelkaMunk function at 700 nm are slower than those with O2.\"\n          [125] \"From this difference in the temporal profiles, it is concluded that the reoxidation of reduced VOx species by N2O is slower than by O2.\"\n          [126] \"Similar results were obtained for other catalytic materials studied.\"\n          [127] \"Taking the difference in the oxidizing ability of O2 and N2O, it is easy to understand why the average oxidation state of VOx species under C3H8O2 conditions is higher than under C3H8N2O (Figure 6).\"\n          [128] \"The lower ability of N2O for reoxidation of reduced VOx species is also responsible for the lower ODP activity with N2O than with O2 as was previously suggested for VOx/MCM-4120 and VOx/γ-Al2O336 catalytic materials.\"\n          [129] \"The effect of oxygen species (lattice oxygen or adsorbed) on the ODP reaction was studied by pulsing a mixture of propane and labeled oxygen (18O2) over the catalyst, which was preoxidized by 16O2.\"\n          [130] \"COx products containing different oxygen isotopes (16O and 18O) were detected at the reactor outlet.\"\n          [131] \"Their transient responses are presented in Figure 7 in a height-normalized form for better comparison of their pulse shapes.\"\n          [132] \"The presence of 16O (not pulsed gas-phase oxygen) in CO and CO2 evidences the participation of lattice oxygen of VOx species in combustion of C3H8/C3H6.\"\n          [133] \"This result is very similar to previous reported ones over various vanadium-based catalytic materials.27,48,49\"\n          [134] \"Since transient responses of carbon oxides contain both labeled (18O) and nonlabeled (16O) oxygen species (Figure 7), two independent reaction pathways in COx formation can be suggested: (1) with participation of labeled (adsorbed) and (2) nonlabeled (lattice) oxygen.\"\n          [135] \"However, the concentration of CO2 and CO formed with participation of labeled oxygen (C18O2, C18O16O, and C18O) was significantly lower than C16O2 and C16O.\"\n          [136] \"This indicates that C16O and C16O2 are the main COx products.\"\n          [137] \"In other words, lattice oxygen of VOx species is mainly responsible for COx formation.\"\n          [138] \"Adsorbed oxygen species formed from gas-phase labeled (18O2) oxygen play only a minor role in COx formation under transient vacuum conditions.\"\n          [139] \"This may be because the concentration of lattice nonlabeled oxygen in VOx species is considerably higher than that of labeled oxygen in the C3H818O2 pulse.\"\n          [140] \"The ratio of vanadium to the amount of 18O2 in one pulse was estimated as ca. 5·104.\"\n          [141] \"However, the contribution of adsorbed oxygen species to the formation of COx can be significantly higher under ambient-pressure conditions.\"\n          [142] \"We would like to emphasize that no labeled oxygen species in COx was observed in our previous experiments over VOx/γ-Al2O3 under similar conditions in the TAP reactor.27\"\n          [143] \"This can be explained by the fact that incorporation of gas-phase oxygen into VOx species occurs considerably faster over VOx/γ-Al2O3 as compared to SiO2-based catalysts.\"\n          [144] \"This assumption is indirectly supported by the recently reported results of the ODP reaction over VOx/Al2O3 50 and VOx/SiO2 51 in cofeed (O2 and C3H8 are fed together) and cyclic (O2 and C3H8 are fed separately and periodically) modes.\"\n          [145] \"No substantial differences in propene selectivity between the cofeed and cyclic conditions were found over the alumina-based catalysts, while propene selectivity over the silica-based one was significantly improved when the ODP reaction was performed under the cyclic conditions.\"\n          [146] \"In the latter case, the negative effect of adsorbed oxygen species on propene selectivity could be avoided.\"\n          [147] \"The results of steady-state ODP studies suggest a complex reaction scheme of parallel and consecutive steps for the ODP reaction using either O2 or N2O.\"\n          [148] \"According to this scheme, C3H8 is directly converted to C3H6 and COx, with the latter reaction path playing a significant role for VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample possessing microcrystalline V2O5.\"\n          [149] \"The formed propene is further converted to CO and CO2.\"\n          [150] \"The importance of direct (not via consecutive propene oxidation) propane and consecutive propene oxidation to COx is significantly higher in the presence of O2 than in N2O.\"\n          [151] \"Hence, the catalytic performance is determined by the oxidant activation.\"\n          [152] \"Combining the results of in-situ UV/vis analysis and transient isotopic experiments with catalytic data, two important conclusions about the role of O2 and N2O in the ODP reaction were derived: (1) the ability of oxidant for reoxidation of reduced VOx species and (2) the nature of selective and nonselective oxygen species.\"\n          [153] \"The former oxidant property tunes the degree of reduction of vanadium species; the lower the oxidizing ability, the higher the reduction degree of VOx species.\"\n          [154] \"This is essential for achieving high primary propene selectivity and for suppressing consecutive propene oxidation to CO and CO2 as shown in Figure 2.\"\n          [155] \"This improving effect of N2O is related to spatial separation of active lattice oxygen species, that is, to reducing surface density of active oxygen species.\"\n          [156] \"Since 710 oxygen atoms are required for COx formation from propane/propene but only one for propene formation, nonselective propane/propene oxidation to COx will be inhibited upon increasing degree of reduction of VOx species.\"\n          [157] \"However, the degree of reduction of VOx species is not the only reason for superior performance of N2O as compared to O2.\"\n          [158] \"On the basis of the results of transient isotopic experiments in section 3.4, it is suggested that the nature of oxygen species influences also the COx formation.\"\n          [159] \"It is well-known 52 that O2 adsorption over reducible metal oxides occurs via a complex sequence of redox processes until O2- (lattice oxygen) is formed.\"\n          [160] \"Density functional theory (DFT) calculations predict that gas-phase oxygen adsorbs molecularly over anion vacancy of reduced VOx species. 53,54\"\n          [161] \"This biatomic adsorbed oxygen dissociates further yielding lattice oxygen species.\"\n          [162] \"Adsorbed (nonlattice) oxygen species were suggested to be nonselective ones for the ODP reaction over VMgO 55,56 and Mn0.18V0.3Cr0.23W0.26OxAl2O3 57 catalytic materials.\"\n          [163] \"In contrast to O2 adsorption, N2O decomposition over reducible metal oxides yields mononuclear oxygen species: O- or O2-, which are considered as selective ones.52\"\n          [164] \"Further experimental mechanistic studies and theoretical (density functional theory) calculations are in progress with the aim to precisely define the nature of oxygen species originating from O2 and N2O over reduced VOx species.\"", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been shown to increase propene selectivity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) over alumina- and silica-supported vanadia catalysts compared to O2. However, the ODP activity with N2O is lower than with O2. The degree of reduction of VOx species is suggested to be important for achieving high propene selectivity. The nature of oxygen species, whether adsorbed (nonlattice) or lattice, also influences COx formation. Adsorbed oxygen species are considered nonselective for the ODP reaction over certain catalysts. The redox dynamics of VOx species have been studied using in-situ UV/vis analysis, and the catalytic performance of different VOx/SiO2, VOx/MCM-41, and VOx/MCM-48 materials in the ODP reaction has been characterized. Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been found to be advantageous as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) compared to other oxidants like oxygen (O2). This is due to its ability to achieve higher propylene selectivity. The study of VOx/MCM-41, VOx/SiO2, and VOx/MCM-48 materials has shown that N2O can lead to a higher degree of reduction of vanadium species, which is essential for achieving high primary propylene selectivity and suppressing consecutive propylene oxidation to CO and CO2. The higher polymerized VOx species have a higher activity for consecutive propene oxidation, and the importance of direct propane oxidation and consecutive propene oxidation to COx is significantly higher in the presence of O2 than in N2O. The catalytic performance is determined by the oxidant activation, and N2O's lower oxidizing ability tunes the degree of reduction of vanadium species, leading to a higher reduction degree of VOx species. This effect is related to the spatial separation of active lattice oxygen species, reducing the surface density of active oxygen species. However, the degree of reduction of VOx species is not the only reason for the superior performance of N2O compared to O2. The nature of oxygen species also influences COx formation, with adsorbed (nonlattice) oxygen species being nonselective for the ODP reaction over certain catalytic materials. In contrast, N2O decomposition over reducible metal oxides yields mononuclear oxygen species, which are considered selective. The critical challenges associated with catalyst deactivation and stability in N2O-ODHP include the need for a high degree of reduction of vanadium species and the prevention of nonselective oxygen species formation. Strategies to address these limitations could involve the development of catalysts with controlled surface density of active oxygen species and the optimization of reaction conditions to favor selective oxygen species formation. Research directions could focus on understanding the mechanisms of oxygen species formation and their role in the selectivity of the ODHP process, as well as the development of new catalyst formulations that can maintain high activity and selectivity under N2O-ODHP conditions. Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been shown to have advantages over other oxidants in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP), particularly in terms of propylene selectivity. The use of N2O as an oxidant results in higher propylene selectivity compared to oxygen (O2) over a broad range of propane conversions. This effect is more pronounced for catalysts with microcrystalline V2O5. The improved selectivity is attributed to the ability of N2O to achieve a higher primary propene selectivity and to lower the activity for consecutive propene oxidation. N2O reoxidizes reduced VOx species slower than O2, which is essential for suppressing nonselective consecutive propene oxidation to COx. The nature of oxygen species also plays a role, with N2O not producing nonselective adsorbed oxygen species that can catalyze nonselective consecutive propene oxidation to COx. A variety of catalysts have been employed in the ODHP process, including VOx/SiO2, VOx/MCM-41, and VOx/MCM-48. These catalysts have been characterized using various techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), UV/vis, Raman, and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The specific surface area of the catalysts decreases with vanadium loading, and the degree of polymerization of VOx species is influenced by the support material. The catalytic activity of the VOx(2.7)/MCM-41 catalyst is slightly higher than that of the VOx(2.8)/SiO2 and VOx(3.4)/MCM-48 samples, possibly due to a lower degree of polymerization of VOx species. The lowest activity was observed over the VOx(11.2)/MCM-41 sample, which possesses microcrystalline V2O5. Catalyst deactivation and stability are critical challenges in the ODHP process. The use of N2O as an oxidant can help mitigate these issues by reducing the formation of nonselective adsorbed oxygen species that can lead to catalyst deactivation. However, the lower activity of N2O compared to O2 can also be a limitation. Strategies to address these challenges include optimizing the catalyst structure and composition to enhance stability and selectivity, developing methods to regenerate deactivated catalysts, and exploring alternative oxidants that can provide high selectivity and activity while maintaining catalyst stability.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮（N2O）作为氧化剂在丙烷氧化脱氢（ODHP）中显示出相对于其他氧化剂的优势，特别是在丙烯选择性方面。使用N2O作为氧化剂可导致与氧气（O2）相比，在广泛的丙烷转化率范围内具有更高的丙烯选择性。这种改善的选择性归因于N2O能够实现更高的初始丙烯选择性，并降低连续丙烯氧化的活性。N2O比O2更慢地重新氧化还原的VOx物种，这对于抑制非选择性的连续丙烯氧化至COx至关重要。氧物种的性质也起着作用，N2O不会产生非选择性的吸附氧物种，这些物种可以催化非选择性的连续丙烯氧化至COx。已经使用了各种催化剂，包括VOx/SiO2、VOx/MCM-41和VOx/MCM-48，在ODHP过程中。这些催化剂使用了包括透射电子显微镜（TEM）、温度程序还原（TPR）、UV/vis、拉曼和X射线衍射（XRD）在内的多种技术进行了表征。随着钒负载量的增加，催化剂的比表面积降低，VOx物种的聚合度受支撑材料的影响。VOx(2.7)/MCM-41催化剂的催化活性略高于VOx(2.8)/SiO2和VOx(3.4)/MCM-48样品，这可能归因于VOx物种较低的聚合度。观察到最低活性是在VOx(11.2)/MCM-41样品上，该样品具有微晶V2O5。催化剂失活和稳定性是ODHP过程中的关键挑战。使用N2O作为氧化剂可以通过减少导致催化剂失活的非选择性吸附氧物种的形成来帮助缓解这些问题。然而，N2O的较低活性与O2相比也可能是一个限制。解决这些挑战的策略包括优化催化剂结构和组成以增强稳定性和选择性，开发方法来再生失活的催化剂，以及探索可以提供高选择性和活性同时保持催化剂稳定性的替代氧化剂。", "Doi": "10.1021/jp070747c"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The influence of adding 300 ppm of N2O in the feed during the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane and 3% of CO2 during the oxidation of methane was studied using a mixture of NiMoO4 and -Sb2O4, and a palladium supported on a mixed Zr-Ce-O oxide catalyst, respectively.\"\n          [2] \"With N2O, the selectivity to propylene increases, while the conversion of both propane and oxygen and the yield in CO2 decreases.\"\n          [3] \"N2O promotes the reduction of molybdenum.\"\n          [4] \"Taking into account the precision in the measurements, in- troduction of N2O in the feed produces significant changes.\"\n          [5] \"When compared with the mixture of NiMoO4 + -Sb2O4 tested in the absence of dope, addition of 300 ppm N2O in the feed induces (Table 2): (i) a weak decrease in the conversion of propane (13%), (ii) a decrease in the yield of CO2 (22%) and (iii) a decrease in the conversion of oxygen (21%). The yield (3.2%) and the selectivity (+8%) in propylene and the selectivity in CO2 (9%) re- main unchanged.\"\n          [6] \"For pure NiMoO4, addition of 300 ppm N2O leads to (Table 2): (i) a decrease in the conversion of propane (15%), (ii) an increase in the selectivity to propylene (+32%), (iii) a decrease in both the conversion of oxygen (19%) and the yield of CO2 (21%).\"\n          [7] \"Under N2O, molybdenum in NiMoO4 works in a slightly more reduced state (XPS: presence of Mo5+). Under these conditions, the catalyst is more selective.\"\n          [8] \"These results could indicate that -Sb2O4 and N2O could probably play the same role, namely, control- ling the selectivity of NiMoO4 during the reaction, inhibit- ing non-selective sites.\"\n          [9] \"The role of -Sb2O4 is to irrigate the surface of MoO3 with spillover oxygen which facilitates the oxida- tion of the surface of MoO3 after incorporation of its oxy- gen atoms in oxidation products.\"\n          [10] \"N2O also facilitates the reduction of the surface of the molybdenum. But the mechanism by which the re- duction of the catalysts is adjusted seems to be different. It could be suggested that N2O inhibits the adsorption of oxy- gen on NiMoO4, so promoting reduction.\"\n          [11] \"The fact that there is no significant increase in the selectivity to propylene when N2O is fed in the mix- ture of NiMoO4 and -Sb2O4 is coherent with this picture.\"\n          [12] \"In the mixture, the selectivity is already largely modulated by -Sb2O4.\"", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) has been used as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) to increase the selectivity to propylene compared to other oxidants. The catalysts employed in this process include a mixture of NiMoO4 and -Sb2O4, and a palladium supported on a mixed Zr-Ce-O oxide catalyst. The addition of N2O in the feed leads to a significant increase in the selectivity to propylene, while the conversion of propane and oxygen and the yield in CO2 decrease. N2O promotes the reduction of molybdenum, which is beneficial for the selectivity of the catalyst. However, the conversion of propane and the yield of CO2 decrease, which may limit the practical application of N2O-ODHP. The challenge of catalyst deactivation and stability is also a critical issue that needs to be addressed. Strategies to improve the stability of the catalysts and reduce the deactivation rate could potentially make N2O-ODHP a more feasible option for practical implementation. For example, the use of more stable catalysts or the development of new catalysts with higher activity and selectivity could be explored. Additionally, the optimization of the reaction conditions, such as temperature, pressure, and feed composition, could also help to improve the stability of the catalysts and reduce the deactivation rate.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮(N2O)已被用作氧化脱氢丙烷(ODHP)的氧化剂,与其它氧化剂相比,它能提高丙烯的选择性。该研究使用了NiMoO4和-Sb2O4的混合物作为催化剂。在进料中添加N2O会导致丙烯的选择性显著提高,而丙烷和氧气的转化率以及CO2的产率下降。N2O促进钼的还原,这对催化剂的选择性有益。然而,丙烷的转化率和CO2的产率下降,这可能限制N2O-ODHP的实际应用。催化剂失活和稳定性的问题也是一个需要解决的关键问题。提高催化剂稳定性和降低失活率的策略可能使N2O-ODHP成为更可行的实用选择。例如,可以探索使用更稳定的催化剂或开发具有更高活性和选择性的新催化剂。此外,优化反应条件,如温度、压力和进料组成,也有助于提高催化剂的稳定性和降低失活率。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.cattod.2004.03.005"},
{"Quotes": "Steam-activated Fe-zeolites (MFI and BEA) are efficient catalysts for the N2O-mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of propane, with ini- tial propylene yields up to 25% at 723 K, but deactivate as a result of coke formation.\n          A tapered element oscillating microbalance (TEOM) coupled to GC analysis has been applied to correlate activity and deactivation by simultaneous measurements of reaction and coking.\n          The presence of extraframework iron species, generated during steam treatment, is essential for producing active catalysts.\n          The nature and dis- tribution of extraframework iron species, the zeolite host, and the catalyst acidity have no significant effect on the initial propene yield, but strongly influence the deactivation behavior.\n          FeZSM-5 shows a remarkable resistance against deactivation, while a very rapid and complete deactivation occurred in FeBEA.\n          The initial propene yield over FeZSM-5 and FeBEA was remarkably higher than over commercial H-ZSM-5 and H-BEA (with 3040 times lower iron content), although the residual activities after 400 min on stream were very similar.\n          The remarkable yields toward propionaldehyde (up to 6%) have been obtained.\n          A major drawback of FeMFI zeo- lites in ODHP with N2O is the deactivation by coke, causing a rapid decrease of the propene yield.\n          The TEOM consists of a microreactor with a high-resolution microbalance that generates real-time measurements of mass changes during gas-solid reactions.\n          The TEOM presents three main advantages over conventional gravimetric microbalances: (i) a well-defined flow pattern, eliminating possible (heat and mass) diffusion and bouyancy phenomena; (ii) a very fast response time res- olution (0.1 s); and (iii) a high mass resolution across the entire range of pressure and temperature.\n          Steam activation is essential for achieving high catalytic activities, as concluded from the low conversion of reactants and propene yield obtained over the calcined iron zeolites.\n          Extraframework iron species, generated during steam treatment, are thus responsible for the oxydehydrogenation of propane with nitrous oxide.\n          The difference in initial C3H6 yield between ex-FeZSM-5 and ex-Fe-silicalite is marginal if their constitution with re- spect to iron is taken into account.\n          The initial activity of the syn- thesized Fe-zeolites, expressed as mole C3H8 converted per unit of time and catalyst mass is 23 higher than over the commercial zeolites, while the former catalysts contain 30 40 times more iron.\n          The rapid deactivation observed in ex-FeBEA and ex- H-BEA can be connected to the presence of large cavities with relatively small apertures in the BEA framework, espe- cially at the intersection of the channels.\n          The rate of deactivation over the MFI catalysts is significantly lower, and can be related to the absence of large cages in this zeolitic structure, since channels and intersections are of similar size.\n          The higher deactivation resistance of steam-activated ex-FeZSM- 5 in ODHP with N2O is unclear at this stage, but can be tentatively related to the different iron constitutions in both catalysts and/or the different porous structure associated to the presence of aluminum in the original zeolite framework.\n          Ex-FeZSM-5 contains mesopores due to dealumination upon steam treatment, which are absent in ex-Fe-silicalite.\n          The more open structure of FeZSM-5 may reduce pore blocking by coke and also to improve transport of reactants and products, slowing down deactivation.\n          The activity of ex-FeZSM-5 in direct N2O decomposition is significantly higher than that of ex-Fe-silicalite.\n          N2O activation generates atomic oxygen over certain iron species, which is efficiently utilized for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane.\n          However, re- combination of atomic oxygen and desorption as O2 may lead to reaction with coke at specific locations of the zeolite at the operating temperature, resulting in COx.\n          This function would partially regenerate the catalyst surface.\n          This hypoth- esis would imply that highly active Fe-zeolite catalysts in direct N2O decomposition have an increased resistance to- ward coke deactivation in ODHP with N2O.", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) is an efficient oxidant for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) over steam-activated Fe-zeolites (MFI and BEA), achieving initial propylene yields up to 25% at 723 K. However, catalyst deactivation occurs due to coke formation.\n          A tapered element oscillating microbalance (TEOM) coupled to GC analysis has been applied to correlate activity and deactivation by simultaneous measurements of reaction and coking.\n          Extraframework iron species, generated during steam treatment, are essential for producing active catalysts.\n          The nature and distribution of extraframework iron species, the zeolite host, and the catalyst acidity have no significant effect on the initial propene yield, but strongly influence the deactivation behavior.\n          FeZSM-5 shows a remarkable resistance against deactivation, while a very rapid and complete deactivation occurred in FeBEA.\n          The initial propene yield over FeZSM-5 and FeBEA was remarkably higher than over commercial H-ZSM-5 and H-BEA (with 3040 times lower iron content), although the residual activities after 400 min on stream were very similar.\n          Remarkable yields toward propionaldehyde (up to 6%) have been obtained.\n          A major drawback of FeMFI zeolites in ODHP with N2O is the deactivation by coke, causing a rapid decrease of the propene yield.\n          The TEOM consists of a microreactor with a high-resolution microbalance that generates real-time measurements of mass changes during gas-solid reactions.\n          The TEOM presents three main advantages over conventional gravimetric microbalances: a well-defined flow pattern, a very fast response time resolution (0.1 s), and a high mass resolution across the entire range of pressure and temperature.\n          Steam activation is essential for achieving high catalytic activities, as concluded from the low conversion of reactants and propene yield obtained over the calcined iron zeolites.\n          Extraframework iron species, generated during steam treatment, are responsible for the oxydehydrogenation of propane with nitrous oxide.\n          The difference in initial C3H6 yield between ex-FeZSM-5 and ex-Fe-silicalite is marginal if their constitution with respect to iron is taken into account.\n          The initial activity of the synthesized Fe-zeolites is significantly higher than over the commercial zeolites, while the former catalysts contain 30 40 times more iron.\n          The rapid deactivation observed in ex-FeBEA and ex-H-BEA can be connected to the presence of large cavities with relatively small apertures in the BEA framework, especially at the intersection of the channels.\n          The rate of deactivation over the MFI catalysts is significantly lower, and can be related to the absence of large cages in this zeolitic structure, since channels and intersections are of similar size.\n          The higher deactivation resistance of steam-activated ex-FeZSM-5 in ODHP with N2O is unclear, but can be tentatively related to the different iron constitutions in both catalysts and/or the different porous structure associated with the presence of aluminum in the original zeolite framework.\n          Ex-FeZSM-5 contains mesopores due to dealumination upon steam treatment, which are absent in ex-Fe-silicalite.\n          The more open structure of FeZSM-5 may reduce pore blocking by coke and also improve transport of reactants and products, slowing down deactivation.\n          The activity of ex-FeZSM-5 in direct N2O decomposition is significantly higher than that of ex-Fe-silicalite.\n          N2O activation generates atomic oxygen over certain iron species, which is efficiently utilized for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane.\n          However, recombination of atomic oxygen and desorption as O2 may lead to reaction with coke at specific locations of the zeolite at the operating temperature, resulting in COx.\n          This function would partially regenerate the catalyst surface.\n          This hypothesis would imply that highly active Fe-zeolite catalysts in direct N2O decomposition have an increased resistance toward coke deactivation in ODHP with N2O.", "Chinese": "使用蒸汽活化Fe-沸石（MFI和BEA）作为催化剂的N2O介导的丙烷氧化脱氢可以达到初始丙烯产量高达25%，温度为723 K。然而，这些催化剂由于焦炭形成而失活。\n          使用与GC分析耦合的锥形元件振荡微天平（TEOM）同时测量反应和焦化，以关联活性和失活。\n          在蒸汽处理过程中生成的框架外铁物种对于产生活性催化剂至关重要。\n          框架外铁物种的性质和分布，沸石宿主和催化剂酸性对初始丙烯产量没有显著影响，但强烈影响失活行为。\n          FeZSM-5显示出对失活的显著抵抗力，而FeBEA则经历了快速和完全的失活。\n          FeZSM-5和FeBEA的初始丙烯产量显著高于商业H-ZSM-5和H-BEA（铁含量低3040倍），尽管400分钟后流过的残余活性非常相似。\n          获得了对丙醛的显著产量（高达6%）。\n          FeMFI沸石在N2O-ODHP中的主要缺点是由于焦炭导致的失活，导致丙烯产量迅速下降。\n          TEOM由一个具有高分辨率微天平的微型反应器组成，可生成气体-固体反应期间质量变化的实时测量。\n          TEOM与传统重力微天平相比具有三个主要优势：明确定义的流型，消除了可能的（热和质量）扩散和浮力现象；非常快的响应时间分辨率（0.1秒）；以及整个压力和温度范围内的高质质量。\n          蒸汽活化对于实现高催化活性至关重要，正如从铁沸石煅烧后反应物和丙烯产量的低转化率得出的结论。\n          在蒸汽处理过程中生成的框架外铁物种负责丙烷与一氧化二氮的氧脱氢。\n          如果考虑到它们相对于铁的组成，ex-FeZSM-5和ex-Fe-silicalite之间的初始C3H6产量之间的差异是微小的。\n          合成Fe-沸石的初始活性，以每单位时间和催化剂质量转换的C3H8摩尔表示，比商业沸石高23倍，而前者催化剂的铁含量高30 40倍。\n          在ex-FeBEA和ex-H-BEA中观察到的快速失活可以与BEA框架中存在大空腔和相对小的开口相关联，特别是在通道的交界处。\n          MFI催化剂的失活速率显著较低，可以与这种沸石结构中不存在大笼子相关，因为通道和交界处的大小相似。\n          蒸汽活化ex-FeZSM-5在N2O-ODHP中的更高失活抗性尚不清楚，但可以暂时与两种催化剂的不同铁组成和/或与原始沸石框架中存在铝相关的不同多孔结构相关。\n          ex-FeZSM-5由于蒸汽处理过程中脱铝而含有介孔，而在ex-Fe-silicalite中不存在。\n          FeZSM-5的更开放结构可能减少焦炭对孔的堵塞，并且还可以改善反应物和产物的运输，从而减缓失活。\n          ex-FeZSM-5在直接N2O分解中的活性显著高于ex-Fe-silicalite。\n          N2O激活在某些铁物种上产生原子氧，这被有效地用于丙烷的氧化脱氢。\n          然而，原子氧的重组和作为O2的解吸可能会导致在操作温度下在沸石的特定位置与焦炭反应，产生COx。\n          这种功能将部分再生催化剂表面。\n          这种假设意味着在直接N2O分解中高度活性的Fe-沸石催化剂在N2O-ODHP中对焦炭失活具有增强的抵抗力。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2004.02.005"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The application of N2O as an oxidant for propane ODH, despite resulting in lower propane conversion,allows higher propene selectivity and lower selectivity to carbon oxides [15].\"\n          [2] \"According to the quoted authors [15], propane- to-propene oxydehydrogenation occurs on vanadyl groups with oxygen removal and subsequent vanadium reduction. Oxidants (O2 or N2O) are responsible for vanadium reoxidation. Reoxidation of vanadium species by oxygen is very fast and results in the temporary formation of peroxovanadates, highly reactive to subsequent propene oxidation. The ability of N2O to reoxidize the reduced vanadium species is less and occurs without the formation of peroxovanadates [16].\"\n          [3] \"It was noted that the higher the reaction temperature the faster the deactivation. The very small amount of coke deposit in the spent catalyst would indicate that the vanadium reduction is responsible for catalyst deactivation.\"\n          [4] \"Reoxidation of vanadium species by oxygen is very fast and results in the temporary formation of peroxovanadates, highly reactive to subsequent propene oxidation. The ability of N2O to reoxidize the reduced vanadium species is less and occurs without the formation of peroxovanadates [16].\"\n          [5] \"Accordingly, it seems that carbonaceous deposit formation may influence catalyst deactivation only slightly and that the reduction of vanadium species is mainly responsible for catalyst deactivation.\"\n          [6] \"To discuss the probable reaction paths of hydrocarbon oxidation, both propane and propene oxidation were conducted at different contact times (1, 1.5, 2.1, and 2.5 s).\"\n          [7] \"The decrease in the contribution of acrolein to propene oxidation products with a prolongation of contact time supports this explanation (Fig. 10). A longer contact time results in an elongated time of interaction of formed acrolein with the surface centers, which results in carbonaceous deposit formation. This may explain the lower selectivity to acrolein. Formation of significant amounts of carbonaceous deposit was confirmed by elemental analysis indicating 1.8% of carbon in the catalyst after 1 h on stream.\"\n          [8] \"Regeneration of the catalyst by heating under N2O at 753 K partly restores the activity, and only reoxidation in the presence of oxygen restores the initial activity (Fig. 4S, Supplementary Materials).\"", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) is used as an oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) due to its ability to achieve higher propene selectivity compared to other oxidants, despite lower propane conversion. This is attributed to the fact that N2O reoxidizes the reduced vanadium species without forming peroxovanadates, which are highly reactive and can lead to the formation of carbon oxides. The use of N2O as an oxidant results in a slower reoxidation process, which allows for a higher selectivity towards propene. However, the catalyst deactivation is a critical challenge in this process, as it is mainly caused by the reduction of vanadium species rather than the formation of carbonaceous deposits. The regeneration of the catalyst by heating under N2O at high temperatures can partly restore its activity, but complete restoration requires reoxidation in the presence of oxygen. To address these limitations and make N2O-ODHP a more feasible option for practical implementation, research directions could focus on developing more stable catalysts that can maintain their activity over longer periods, optimizing the reaction conditions to minimize vanadium reduction, and exploring alternative regeneration methods that can effectively restore the catalyst's activity without the need for high-temperature treatments.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮(N2O)作为氧化脱氢丙烷(ODHP)的氧化剂,由于其能够实现比其他氧化剂更高的丙烯选择性,尽管丙烷转化率较低。这归因于N2O能够还原钒物种而不形成过氧钒酸盐,过氧钒酸盐具有高反应性,可导致碳氧化物的形成。使用N2O作为氧化剂导致较慢的再氧化过程,这允许更高的丙烯选择性。然而,催化剂失活是该过程中的一个关键挑战,因为它主要是由钒物种的还原引起的,而不是碳质沉积物的形成。通过在高温下在N2O下加热催化剂,可以部分恢复其活性,但完全恢复需要在氧气存在下进行再氧化。为了解决这些限制,使N2O-ODHP成为更可行的实践实施选项,研究方向可以集中在开发更稳定的催化剂,这些催化剂可以在更长的时间内保持其活性,优化反应条件以最小化钒还原,并探索可以有效恢复催化剂活性而无需高温处理的替代再生方法。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2015.12.028"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"N2O improves selectivity, probably by: (i) inhibiting the adsorption of O2 and/or (ii) increasing reduction rate of the catalysts.\"\n          [2] \"In presence of N2O, catalytic sites work in a more reduced state.\"\n          [3] \"N2O inhibits the adsorption of O2, so limiting the formation of non-selective oxygen species (from O2) and/or the oxidation rate of the catalysts.\"\n          [4] \"The Oproduced by dissociation of N2O can oxidise propane to propene.\"\n          [5] \"Adjusting the concentration of promoters could be an useful tool to modulate selectivity during the catalytic reaction.\"", "English": "Nitrous oxide (N2O) can improve the selectivity of the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) process by inhibiting the adsorption of O2 and/or increasing the reduction rate of the catalysts. The oxygen produced by the dissociation of N2O can oxidize propane to propene. In the presence of N2O, catalytic sites work in a more reduced state. N2O has been used as a pure oxidant in various reactions, including the oxidative coupling of methane to ethane, the transformation of benzene to phenol, and the oxidation of ethylene to epoxide. The use of N2O in ODHP can potentially lead to higher propylene selectivity compared to other oxidants by controlling the oxidation state of the catalyst and limiting the formation of non-selective oxygen species. Adjusting the concentration of N2O could be a useful strategy to modulate selectivity during the catalytic reaction.", "Chinese": "一氧化二氮（N2O）可以通过抑制O2的吸附和/或增加催化剂的还原速率来提高丙烷氧化脱氢（ODHP）过程的选择性。N2O分解产生的氧可以将丙烷氧化为丙烯。在N2O存在下，催化位点处于更还原的状态。N2O已被用作各种反应中的纯氧化剂，包括甲烷氧化偶联为乙烷、苯转化为酚以及乙烯氧化为环氧乙烷。在ODHP中使用N2O可以通过控制催化剂的氧化状态和限制非选择性氧物种的形成，从而与其它氧化剂相比，可能产生更高的丙烯选择性。调整N2O的浓度可能是一种在催化反应中调节选择性的有用策略。", "Doi": "10.1016/S0920-5861(03)00120-2"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"When using nitrous oxide instead of molecular oxygen as oxidizing agent, propene selectivity was also signifi- cantly improved over steam-activated iron-containing zeolites [19], bulk vanadium oxides [20] and supported vanadium-contain- ing materials [13,2123].\"\n          [2] \"A similar effect of N2O was also reported for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane over vanadium magnesium oxide catalysts [24].\"\n          [3] \"Based on a kinetic analysis of the ODP reaction [13,14,25], the positive effect of N2O on the ODP reaction was explained as follows. In contrast to O2, reoxida- tion of reduced VOx species is slower with N2O, resulting in a lower steady-state concentration of active lattice oxygen sites. conversion of approximately 10%.\"\n          [15] \"Since several of the previously postulated oxygen species were paramagnetic, we applied EPR spectroscopy under controlled atmosphere conditions in
